the qustion: A prefix is attached to the beginning of a word/root and often indicates number, time, position, measurement, direction, or negation.
explanation: True — Definition and roles of prefixes are listed on the slide. (Slide p. 7)

the qustion: The combining vowel in medical terms is most commonly 'o'.
explanation: True — Slide notes combining vowel is usually 'o' (sometimes 'i' or 'e'). (Slide p. 23)

the qustion: Combining forms are created by joining a word root with a combining vowel.
explanation: True — Definition of combining forms on the slide. (Slide p. 23)

the qustion: Gastr/o is the combining form meaning liver.
explanation: False — Gastr/o = stomach; Hepat/o = liver. (Slide p. 24)

the qustion: Hepat/o is the combining form for liver.
explanation: True — Examples of combining forms include Hepat/o = liver. (Slide p. 24)

the qustion: Immun/o refers to the immune system or safety.
explanation: True — Immun/o = immune/safe per examples list. (Slide p. 24)

the qustion: Oste/o is a combining form meaning bone.
explanation: True — Oste/o = bone. (Slide p. 24)

the qustion: The prefix hyper- means high or above; brady- means slow; tachy- means fast.
explanation: True — Speed/level prefixes appear together on the slide. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Pre- means after and Post- means before.
explanation: False — Pre- = before; Post- = after. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Retro- means backward.
explanation: True — Time/direction prefixes include retro- = backward. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Neo- means new.
explanation: True — Neo- = new on the time prefix slide. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Ante- means before.
explanation: True — Ante- is listed as before on the time slide. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Leuk- refers to white; Erythr- to red; Cyan- to blue.
explanation: True — Color prefixes are listed explicitly. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: The negation prefixes a-/an- mean without; anti- means against.
explanation: True — Negation slide shows a-/an- = without, anti- = against. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Dys- means abnormal/difficult/impaired.
explanation: True — ABNORMAL slide: dys-. (Slide p. 14)

the qustion: Mono- means single; Oligo- means few; Poly- means many; Bi- two; Tri- three.
explanation: True — NUMBERING slide lists these quantity prefixes. (Slide p. 15)

the qustion: Suffixes add meaning such as condition, procedure, or disease at the start of a word.
explanation: False — Suffixes are attached at the end of a word/root. (Slide p. 16)

the qustion: -itis denotes inflammation.
explanation: True — Condition/symptom suffixes include -itis = inflammation. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: -algia denotes pain.
explanation: True — Condition/symptom suffixes include -algia = pain. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: -emia denotes a blood condition.
explanation: True — Condition/symptom suffixes include -emia = blood condition. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: -osis denotes an abnormal condition.
explanation: True — Condition/symptom suffixes include -osis = abnormal condition. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: -oma denotes tumor or swelling.
explanation: True — Condition/symptom suffixes include -oma. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: -megaly means enlargement.
explanation: True — Listed under condition/progress suffixes. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: -genesis relates to development/formation.
explanation: True — Development noted on suffix slide. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: -stasis means stop/control.
explanation: True — Stop/control listed on suffix slide. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: -gram is a record; -graph is the instrument; -graphy is the process of recording.
explanation: True — Procedures/tests slide lists distinctions among gram/graph/graphy. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: -scope is an instrument for examining; -meter is for measuring.
explanation: True — Procedures/tests instrument suffixes. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Word roots provide the fundamental meaning of a medical term.
explanation: True — Definition of word roots on the slide. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Most medical words contain at least one word root.
explanation: True — Stated on word roots slide. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Arthritis means inflammation of a joint.
explanation: True — Arthr- (joint) + -itis (inflammation); appears in examples list. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Myalgia means muscle pain.
explanation: True — My- (muscle) + -algia (pain); also appears in practice list. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Hepatomegaly means small liver.
explanation: False — Hepat/o = liver; -megaly = enlargement → enlarged liver. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Apnea literally means without breathing.
explanation: True — a-/an- = without; -pnea relates to breathing; term appears in the practice list. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Hematuria means blood in the urine.
explanation: True — Practice slide includes 'Hematuria'. Root hema- (blood) + -uria (urine). (Slide p. 44)

the qustion: Dysuria means painful or difficult urination.
explanation: True — Practice slide includes 'Dysuria'. dys- (difficult) + -uria (urine). (Slide p. 44)

the qustion: Combining vowels are never used when joining two roots.
explanation: False — Combining vowels help connect elements; commonly 'o'. (Slide p. 23)

the qustion: The combining vowel is usually dropped if the suffix begins with a vowel.
explanation: True — General rule taught alongside combining forms. (Slide p. 23)

the qustion: Hepat/o + -itis becomes hepatitis (no connecting 'o' needed).
explanation: True — Drop the 'o' before a vowel-beginning suffix in standard construction. (Slide p. 23)

the qustion: Medical terminology improves clarity in documentation and communication.
explanation: True — Summary slide emphasizes clarity in patient information sharing. (Slide p. 45)

the qustion: The ingredient 'word root' carries the core meaning of the term, while prefixes/suffixes modify that meaning.
explanation: True — Word root = fundamental meaning; affixes modify context such as time, number, condition, or procedure. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Which prefix means 'fast'?
explanation: Correct: Tachy-. Tachy- = fast/rapid; brady- = slow; hyper- = above/high; hypo- = below/under. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which prefix means 'slow'?
explanation: Correct: Brady-. Brady- = slow. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which prefix means 'high or above'?
explanation: Correct: Hyper-. Hyper- = above/high; hypo- = below/under. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which prefix means 'before'?
explanation: Correct: Pre-. Pre- = before; post- = after; retro- = backward; neo- = new. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Which prefix means 'after'?
explanation: Correct: Post-. Post- = after. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Which prefix means 'backward'?
explanation: Correct: Retro-. Retro- = backward. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Which prefix means 'new'?
explanation: Correct: Neo-. Neo- = new. (Slide p. 10)

the qustion: Which color prefix matches 'white'?
explanation: Correct: Leuk-. Leuk- = white; erythr- = red; cyan- = blue. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which color prefix matches 'red'?
explanation: Correct: Erythr-. Erythr- = red. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which color prefix matches 'blue'?
explanation: Correct: Cyan-. Cyan- = blue. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which negation prefix means 'without'?
explanation: Correct: A-/An-. a-/an- = without; anti- = against; dys- = abnormal/difficult. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Which prefix means 'abnormal/difficult'?
explanation: Correct: Dys-. Dys- indicates abnormal or difficult. (Slide p. 14)

the qustion: Which quantity prefix means 'few'?
explanation: Correct: Oligo-. Oligo- = few; poly- = many; mono- = single. (Slide p. 15)

the qustion: Which quantity prefix means 'many/multiple'?
explanation: Correct: Poly-. Poly- = many/multiple. (Slide p. 15)

the qustion: Which suffix means 'inflammation'?
explanation: Correct: -itis. -itis = inflammation; -algia = pain; -emia = blood condition; -osis = abnormal condition. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which suffix means 'pain'?
explanation: Correct: -algia. -algia = pain. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which suffix means 'blood condition'?
explanation: Correct: -emia. -emia = blood condition. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which suffix means 'abnormal condition'?
explanation: Correct: -osis. -osis = abnormal condition. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which suffix means 'tumor'?
explanation: Correct: -oma. -oma = tumor/swelling. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which suffix means 'enlargement'?
explanation: Correct: -megaly. -megaly = enlargement. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which suffix relates to 'development/formation'?
explanation: Correct: -genesis. -genesis = development/formation. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which suffix means 'stop/control'?
explanation: Correct: -stasis. -stasis = stop/control. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which suffix means 'record' (a product of recording)?
explanation: Correct: -gram. -gram = record; -graph = instrument; -graphy = process. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which suffix means 'process of recording'?
explanation: Correct: -graphy. -graphy = process of recording. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which suffix means 'instrument for recording'?
explanation: Correct: -graph. -graph = instrument for recording. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which suffix means 'instrument for examining'?
explanation: Correct: -scope. -scope = instrument for examining. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which suffix means 'instrument for measuring'?
explanation: Correct: -meter. -meter = instrument for measuring. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which combining form means 'stomach'?
explanation: Correct: Gastr/o. Gastr/o = stomach. (Slide p. 24)

the qustion: Which combining form means 'liver'?
explanation: Correct: Hepat/o. Hepat/o = liver. (Slide p. 24)

the qustion: Which combining form means 'immune/safe'?
explanation: Correct: Immun/o. Immun/o = immune/safe. (Slide p. 24)

the qustion: Which combining form means 'bone'?
explanation: Correct: Oste/o. Oste/o = bone. (Slide p. 24)

the qustion: Which term best means 'inflammation of a joint'?
explanation: Correct: Arthritis. Arthr- (joint) + -itis (inflammation). (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which term best means 'enlarged liver'?
explanation: Correct: Hepatomegaly. Hepat/o (liver) + -megaly (enlargement). (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which term best means 'pain in muscle'?
explanation: Correct: Myalgia. My- (muscle) + -algia (pain). (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which term best means 'without breathing'?
explanation: Correct: Apnea. a-/an- = without; -pnea = breathing. (Slide p. 13)

the qustion: Which term best means 'blood in urine'?
explanation: Correct: Hematuria. Hema- (blood) + -uria (urine). (Slide p. 44)

the qustion: Which term best means 'difficult urination'?
explanation: Correct: Dysuria. Dys- = difficult/abnormal + -uria (urination). (Slide p. 44)

the qustion: The combining vowel is usually dropped when the suffix begins with a:
explanation: Correct: Vowel. Drop the 'o' before a vowel-beginning suffix (e.g., hepat + -itis = hepatitis). (Slide p. 23)

the qustion: Which correctly forms a term meaning 'record of the heart'?
explanation: Correct: Cardiogram. -gram = record; cardi/o (heart) + gram. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which correctly names the instrument used to examine the stomach?
explanation: Correct: Gastroscope. -scope = instrument for examining; gastr/o = stomach. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which correctly names the process of recording brain activity?
explanation: Correct: Neurography. -graphy = process of recording. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which prefix pair is correctly matched?
explanation: Correct: Tachy- = fast. Tachy- = fast/rapid. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which quantity prefix is correctly paired?
explanation: Correct: Mono- = single. Mono- = single; poly- = many; oligo- = few; bi- = two; tri- = three. (Slide p. 15)

the qustion: Pick the correct meaning: 'Leukocyte'
explanation: Correct: White cell. Leuk- = white; -cyte = cell. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Pick the correct meaning: 'Cyanosis'
explanation: Correct: Blue discoloration. Cyan- = blue; -osis = abnormal condition/appearance. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Pick the correct meaning: 'Erythremia'
explanation: Correct: Condition of red (cells/blood). Erythr- = red; -emia = blood condition. (Slide p. 12)

the qustion: Which is the best translation for 'osteitis'?
explanation: Correct: Bone inflammation. Oste/o = bone; -itis = inflammation. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which is the best translation for 'nephrosis'?
explanation: Correct: Abnormal kidney condition. Nephr/o = kidney; -osis = abnormal condition. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which is the best translation for 'arthroplasty'?
explanation: Correct: Surgical repair/reconstruction of a joint. -plasty = surgical repair/reconstruction (procedure). (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which is the best translation for 'gastrectomy'?
a: Creation of an opening in stomach
explanation: Correct: Surgical removal of the stomach (part/all). -ectomy = surgical removal; -otomy = incision; -ostomy = creation of an opening. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which is the best translation for 'tracheostomy'?
a: Creation of an opening into the trachea
explanation: Correct: Creation of an opening into the trachea. -ostomy = creation of an opening. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which is the best translation for 'neurotomy'?
explanation: Correct: Incision into a nerve. -otomy = incision; neur/o = nerve. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which term correctly means 'study of the liver'?
explanation: Correct: Hepatology. -logy = study of (commonly taught with condition/procedure suffixes). (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which term is formed correctly (drop the combining vowel)?
explanation: Correct: Hepatology. Drop 'o' before vowel-beginning suffix (hepat + -ology is acceptable; -itis requires dropping 'o'). (Slide p. 23)

the qustion: Which is the correct plural for 'diagnosis' by standard medical pluralization?
explanation: Correct: Diagnoses. '-is' → '-es' is the standard pattern (commonly covered with word-building rules). (Slide p. 23)

the qustion: Which is the correct plural of 'vertebra'?
explanation: Correct: Vertebrae. '-a' → '-ae'. (Slide p. 23)

the qustion: Which is the correct plural of 'bacterium'?
explanation: Correct: Bacteria. '-um' → '-a'. (Slide p. 23)

the qustion: Which best describes the role of the word root?
explanation: Correct: Provides the fundamental meaning. Word root carries core meaning. (Slide p. 21)

the qustion: Which best describes 'combining form'?
explanation: Correct: Root + combining vowel. Combining form = root joined with a combining vowel. (Slide p. 23)

the qustion: Which prefix best completes: _____cardia (slow heart rate)
explanation: Correct: Brady-. Bradycardia: brady- = slow. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which prefix best completes: _____tension (high blood pressure)
explanation: Correct: Hyper-. Hypertension: hyper- = high/above. (Slide p. 9)

the qustion: Which term means 'surgical removal of the kidney'?
explanation: Correct: Nephrectomy. -ectomy = removal; -otomy = incision; -ostomy = opening; -scopy = viewing. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which term means 'instrument for measuring pressure'?
explanation: Correct: Tonometer. -meter = instrument for measuring. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which term means 'record of brain electrical activity'?
explanation: Correct: Electroencephalogram. -gram = record; EEG is the record of brain electrical activity. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which is the best meaning of 'hematology'?
explanation: Correct: Study of blood. Hemat/o = blood; -logy = study of. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which is the correct construction rule example?
explanation: Correct: Gastr/o + -itis = gastritis. Drop the 'o' before vowel-beginning suffix. (Slide p. 23)

the qustion: Which completing suffix yields 'inflammation of the stomach lining'?
explanation: Correct: Gastr/o + -itis. Gastritis. (Slide p. 19)

the qustion: Which best translates 'neuroplasty'?
explanation: Correct: Surgical repair of a nerve. -plasty = surgical repair. (Slide p. 20)

the qustion: Which is the correct plural for 'ovum'?
explanation: Correct: Ova. '-um' → '-a' is the standard pluralization pattern. (Slide p. 23)

the qustion: Which best completes: ______therapy (treatment by writing/record)?
explanation: Correct: -graphy. -graphy means process of recording; in word-building, therapy terms may combine with appropriate suffixes (focus here on suffix meaning). (Slide p. 20)
